newsitem.title: KENYA: Kenyan reformers to stage rally in Mombasa June 7.
newsitem.headline: Kenyan reformers to stage rally in Mombasa June 7.

text.p: Kenya's opposition parties, civic bodies and church groups said on Monday they would hold an "illegal" rally in the coastal resort of Mombasa on Saturday in a campaign to force President Daniel arap Moi to effect minimal constitutional reforms before elections later this year.

Their announcement at a news conference came as hundreds of heavily-armed police patrolled a section of Nairobi after the government blamed street hawkers for weekend rioting. That rioting was sparked by the breaking up by police of a peaceful opposition rally on Saturday called to press for constitutional change.

"We will continue to demonstrate to the president that Kenyans want minimal reforms before the general elections," said lawyer Gibson Kamau Kuria of the coalition National Convention for Constitutional Reform.
"The next meeting will be in Mombasa this weekend. Others will follow in both Nairobi and the provinces," he added. "We believe we can persuade Moi to effect these reforms."

One person was stabbed to death on Saturday after security forces broke up a banned rally called by opposition leaders and church groups demanding constitutional reform. The riot continued on a smaller scale in the run-down outer business district on Sunday.
At least 133 people were arrested during weekend rioting and would be charged with "criminal offences", the government said in a statement on Sunday.
It said 22 policemen and dozens of civilians were injured during the rioting, 61 shops were looted, two cars were burnt and dozens of others stoned.
